urn:contentItem:416M-C4M0-009B-G06Y-00000-00Punishing Sell-Off Hits Wall Street; Oil Prices Spike Higher Once Again; AT&T, British Telecom in Advanced Talks Toward Major Restructuring2000-09-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:25ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30David Bradley, Bill MeehanBusinessSHOW00091500V19Punishing Sell-Off Hits Wall Street; Oil Prices Spike Higher Once Again; AT&T, British Telecom in Advanced Talks Toward Major RestructuringStuart Varney, Willow Bay, Robert Thomson, Terry Keenan, John Metaxas, Susan Lisovicz, Amanda Lang, Kelli Arena, Joie Chen, Allan Chernoff, Ceci Rodgers. Peter Viles

Techs tumbled on Wall Street today, taking a huge bite out of both the Dow and the Nasdaq. The Dow industrials posted its biggest one-day loss since July, dropping back below that key 11000 level, and the Nasdaq fared even worse. Plus, AT&T has been under intense pressure recently to jumpstart its stock, one of the worst Dow performers this year, and management has been considering all its options. Now AT&T is in serious talks with British Telecom about combining two of their divisions to create brand new, stand- alone companies. Also, oil prices shot to the highest levels since the Gulf War today, as the White House warned Iraq about renewed tension in the Middle East.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

STUART VARNEY, CO-HOST: Tonight on MONEYLINE, a punishing sell- off hits Wall Street: nearly $200 billion in value wiped out, the Dow's worst session in months.

WILLOW BAY, CO-HOST: Fueling fear in the markets: oil prices, spiking higher once again. How much of a threat is sky-high oil to the global economy?

VARNEY: And, billions of consumers have been served, but investors are feeling very unsatisfied. The bottom line on McDonalds.

ANNOUNCER: This is MONEYLINE. Reporting tonight from Los Angeles, Willow Bay; and from New York, Stuart Varney.

BAY: Good evening, everyone, and welcome to MONEYLINE. I'm Willow Bay.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney. It was a big day in the markets, but first we have a breaking story for you, and that breaking news involves AT&T.

The company has been under intense pressure recently to jump- start the stock, one of the worst Dow performers this year; and management has been considering all its options, some of them quite dramatic.

Now the "Financial Times" is reporting that AT&T is in serious talks with British Telecom about one of those options: combining two of their divisions to create brand new, stand-alone companies.

Let's go right to Richard -- to Robert Thomson of the "Financial Times" with all the details -- Robert.

ROBERT THOMSON, "FINANCIAL TIMES": Stuart, that's right. This is an extraordinary deal between two telecom titans. Essentially, AT&T and BT are in serious negotiations about spinning off their business service division, their cellular division, and then each concentrating on their domestic markets.

So two would become four.

VARNEY: So they would combine wireless, combine business services and then spin off both, is that correct?

THOMSON: That's correct, that's what they're negotiating at the moment. And one of the things that, particularly, BT is interested in is the market reaction to these talks, and news of these talks.

It was, essentially, AT&T who dialed up BT and said, we need to do a deal. Both companies' share prices have been down 50 percent this year. Incremental increases in business is not going to make the difference that the market wants.

VARNEY: It sounds a little like there might be some desperation in the air, given what's happened to both companies' stock price this year.

THOMSON: Well, BT, this year, has already announced a restructuring which didn't go down well, and I think executives at both companies, AT&T in particular, realize they have to do something dramatic.

And AT&T and BT getting together is definitely dramatic.

VARNEY: If these combinations take place, and the spinoffs take place, doesn't that amount to the break up of AT&T as we know it?

THOMSON: Absolutely, and to the break-up of BT as we know it. So these two companies, which have really been emblematic of each country's telecoms industry, would be something completely different.

VARNEY: Yes, but Robert, AT&T and BT have a joint venture already. I believe it is called Concert. How's that going?

THOMSON: That's correct, Stuart; and it's going very poorly.

They really haven't concentrated on the international business market. They haven't been committed to the project. BT has already set up almost a competitor company, which is focusing on business services.

Essentially, these two companies are now saying, we have to have a proper commitment. We have to compete in a market that's both lucrative and ultra-competitive, and they way to do that is by blending our strengths.

VARNEY: Robert Thomson, the "Financial Times" reporting the story, thank you very much, Robert.

Now, AT&T's stock did edge higher today, but that's little consolation for investors. The stock has gotten slammed over the past year, it's down nearly 50 percent from its 52-week high -- Willow.

BAY: Stuart, our other top story tonight: a crushing session on Wall Street. Investors plagued by the fear of soaring oil prices and slumping corporate profits.

Tech stocks, in particular, took it on the chin, even though industry bellwether Oracle released profits last night that beat expectations. The blue chip tech names accounted for a third of the Dow's 160-point loss today, its worst point drop since late July. The index lost more than 293 on the week.

And on the Nasdaq, Oracle was a major contributor to a big tumble, the index losing more than 78 to close at 3,835. For the week, the Nasdaq fell for than 3 1/2 percent.

The S&P 500 fell 15, about 1 percent. Its weekly loss: more than 28 points.

Today's sell-off came despite some stellar news on inflation: the Consumer Price Index taking its first monthly retreat in 14 years. But that news did nothing to inspire a rally in the bond pits. The 10-year note fell 13/32, the yield at 5.84 percent. The 30-year issue fell more than a full point for the second day in a row. The yield there? 5.90 percent.

So what was behind today's market rout? In part, fear that the world's biggest economy may be headed for a hard landing.

Let's check in with Terry Keenan with more on that and a look at the day's big movers -- Terry.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Willow, if this week's market seemed as confusing as it was difficult, that's because, increasingly, many of the assumptions that had gone unquestioned here have been held up for examination this week.

Chief among them, a conviction that the Federal Reserve has successfully engineered a soft landing. With oil prices rising above $36 a barrel today, there is growing anxiety that the economy will slow down too much, and that's what hit the tech stocks and the economically sensitive names today.

Let's look at the damage report for the Dow, starting with two of the Dow's big tech components.

Hewlett Packard being hammered again today. It has had only one winning session so far this month and is more than 30 percent off of its high of 155.

And take a look at Microsoft, trading at 64 3/16, it's just a couple dollars away from a new multi-year low -- that stock down 45 percent year-to-date.

J.P. Morgan also feeling the heat, as you can see, there, a big decline for that stock, as did G.E. lose ground today in very heavy trading.

Oil the only bright spot among the Dow 30, as Exxon Mobil moved to a new high on that spike in oil prices.

With many of the economically sensitive stocks under pressure, no surprise that losers swamped winners here by a 17 to 10 margin. Volume was the heaviest in weeks, options expiration the reason why. And taking a look at where the big money was coming and going today: Nortel Networks continues to pull out of its early-September slump. Corning, though, down 2 3/8, and Lucent fractionally lower.

Chase lost more than $1, and you saw that impact on J.P. Morgan. Citigroup also weaker, down nearly a buck. Some of the story stocks that we're following for you tonight include Xerox. It was up on some takeover speculation reported in the latest edition of "Business Week."

Bank One getting an underperform as BankAmerica securities initiates coverage. Warren Buffett, by the way, has been nibbling on that stock of late. Pentair a stand-out loser on the session, warning that third quarter earnings will disappoint.

And, finally, Carnival Cruise Lines getting a nice pop after its main competitor, Premier Cruise Lines went into receivership; and, Willow, after a week like this, we could probably all use a cruise -- the Dow down more than 2 1/2 percent.

BAY: Only good news about the week, Terry: it's over.

Terry Keenan, thanks.

September is living up to its reputation as the cruelest month for stocks, especially for technology stocks.

The Nasdaq has plunged nearly nine percent so far this month, while the Dow is down just 2.5 percent. And today it was some of the biggest and most important tech stocks on Wall Street that got beaten up the most.

John Metaxas joins us now with a roundup of all the Nasdaq action -- John.

JOHN METAXAS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Willow, of course the catalyst today was Oracle and, as one analyst said to me today, you had the look pretty deep into Oracle's numbers to find something to get angry about. Well, that's what Wall Street did today, focusing not on the fact that they beat expectations, not on the fact that they announced the two-for-one stock split, which generally is viewed positively, but on weakness in their applications-software segment.

And this was the result: Oracle down 7.8 percent on the day, setting the tone for the entire Nasdaq. Helping to pull the other big cap stocks down with it.

Intel losing 3.7 percent on the day. The semiconductor sector was down 3 percent as a whole. In fact, every sector here was substantially lower on the day.

It wasn't all negative on the earnings front: Adobe beat expectations yesterday with their results. They announced a two-for- one stock split, Merrill Lynch raised their earning estimate and reiterated a buy rating on the stock. This stock reacted as you would expect when a company has good news. But on the other side, we had earning warnings from PSI Net, hammering that stock. A warning from Anadigics, that stock down 16 percent on the day.

If there was any ray of sunshine, it was the performance of Cisco systems; down below $60 early in the day, it rallied in the afternoon to close with a strong gain. Some think as Cisco goes, so goes the Nasdaq, maybe there's a ray of hope.

John Metaxas reporting from the Nasdaq market site.

VARNEY: Aside from the tech tremors, concerns about oil swept in today to rattle the markets.

After a few days of relative calm, oil prices came surging back with a vengeance today. Light sweet crude touched a new 10-year high, ending up $1.85 at $35.92 a barrel.

Susan Lisovicz joins us now to help answer the critical question: What is driving oil higher? Susan.

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Stuart, the situation is so dire President Clinton today said he's considering tapping into the nation's strategic oil reserve.

Both man and nature are to blame for the latest spike in oil prices.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(voice-over): A tropical storm brewing in the Gulf of Mexico, a vital oil-producing region, is only one culprit in the latest spike in crude prices.

Traders also fear renewed threats from Iraq, which has accused neighboring Kuwait of stealing oil from its fields. Such talk preceded Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 and the Gulf War.

But the escalating price of oil has already caused much tension in Europe, where trucker protests have spread beyond Britain, France and Belgium to Spain, Ireland and Poland; and there is increasing uncertainty in the oil trading pits about forecasts that say things could get much worse before they get better.

FADEL GHEIT, FAHNESTOCK AND COMPANY: We should be ready for $40 oil soon, we're only $4 away from here, we're going into the weekend; and if or when Iraq, for any reason, stops producing oil, I think people should be looking for $50 oil, not $40 oil.

LISOVICZ: These projections come the same week that OPEC agreed to boost output by 800,000 barrels a day starting in October. But when oil prices still moved higher, the cartel said it could raise output again. But that still doesn't erase the consequences if oil suddenly stopped flowing from Iraq.

JOHN LICHTBLAU, CHAIRMAN, PETROLEUM INDUSTRY RESEARCH FOUNDATION: If Iraq does take any action, military action, it would immediately be cut off all exports. If that's the case, there's a problem, because the world has very little spare capacity.

LISOVICZ: Analysts say OPEC is now pumping more oil than it has at any time in the past 20 years and that only Saudi Arabia has any spare production capacity. President Clinton says he sees no immediate threat to the U.S. economy.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LISOVICZ: But the U.S. Labor Department says consumer inflation, the Federal Reserve's key reason for raising interest rates, could worsen substantially this month because of the sharp increase in oil prices -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Susan Lisovicz, thanks very much -- Willow.

BAY: Stuart, still to come on MONEYLINE, what's next for techs? Forget Nasdaq 5000 or even 4000. We'll ask one strategist why the tech index could be headed all the way back to 3000.

Plus, the ongoing problems facing Ford Motor, the very latest in the tire recall and whether its shares are a buy, hold or sell.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Checking tonight's "MONEYLINE Movers," Red Hat lost more than 4. Several brokerages downgraded the Linux player today on concerns of future revenue growth. That despite the company reporting a narrower-than-expected second quarter loss late yesterday.

Pentair plunged nearly 7 3/4. Its a maker of power tools and electrical equipment. It warned today that its third quarter earnings would be significantly lower than expected.

Siebel Systems gained almost 4 1/4. J.P. Morgan started coverage of the customer service software maker today with a buy rating and a $115 price target.

And Juniper Networks gained almost 3. UBS Warburg repeated its buy rating today and upped its price target to $250.

A few stocks making big moves after the bell tonight, for a look at all the late action, we go now to the CNNfn newsroom, where Amanda Lang is standing by -- Amanda.

AMANDA LANG, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Net2Phone is on the rise in after-hours trading and pretty decent volume, too. It's gaining more than 2 1/2, this because of reports it will team with Cisco to form a company for Internet telephony. That's one the watch on Monday when that announcement is expected.

American Management Systems not so lucky. This company thinks slower revenue is going to hurt it's third quarter. that has the stock down about 3 1/2 in after-hours trading. Third-quarter earnings are expected to be 28-33 cents now, not the 47 cents analysts have been looking for.

And Autobytel the opposite problem. Better revenue is going to push that company to a better third quarter and full year. This company is rising after-hours. It's trading now up at 5 3/4.

And finally, AT&T, "FT" reported that it may be merging with British Telecom. That stock is rising after hours but in very light trade, so likely that announcement will have more affect in regular trading on Monday.

Back to Stuart.

VARNEY: And that is Amanda Lang.

Bridgestone/Firestone officials today filed depositions in the first defective tires case against the company scheduled to go to trial. Ford Motor also faces a number of lawsuits because of those tire troubles. But analysts are optimistic, after hearing from the company's chief executive in New York this morning.

Kelli Arena reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KELLI ARENA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Ford CEO Jacques Nasser told Wall Street analysts today what he told lawmakers in Washington earlier this week.

JACQUES NASSER, PRESIDENT & CEO, FORD MOTOR: We know this is a Firestone tire issue, not a vehicle issue.

ARENA: Even so, Ford told analysts in New York that its Firestone tire recall problems will affect the company's results for the rest of the year. Most auto analysts have already lowered estimates for the second quarter.

DAVID GARRITY, DRESDNER KLEINWORT BENSON: Our present estimate is about 50 cents a share. We're staying with that. We had brought it down yesterday more because of the impact of the petrol crisis over in Europe.

ARENA: If second quarter earnings do fall below 54 cents a share, it would be the first time in 17 quarters Ford has not seen a gain. But Wall Street sees Ford's problems as temporary. For example, Ford lost about $100 million because it shut down three plants to make tires available for the recall. Those plants will reopen Monday.

SCOTT MERLIS, WASSERSTEIN PERELLA: This stock is a buy because there's $20 billion in cash. The Explorer's doing well, and the Ford is returning cash to the shareholders. And they have a great product plan going forward, and the new Explorer looks very strong. And the new Explorer should do well, just like the old Explorer.

ARENA: Other reasons analysts are optimistic includes Ford's $5 billion stock buy-back program. It's also in the news that Ford took off -- took their table -- took their bid off the table for DaewooMotor in Korea. Investors will probably look at that well from the standpoint that Daewoo was making losses.

ARENA: Ford will continue to face some negative publicity.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ARENA: On Monday, safety regulators are expected to release a new death and injury toll, the result of tire failures. Congress is also expected to schedule at least one more hearing on the issue -- Stuart.

VARNEY: That's Kelli Arena in Washington. Thank you, Kelli.

May I just clarify the story about AT&T and BT. The "Financial Times" is reporting that the wireless operations of those two companies could be merged and then spun off, also the business services businesses of both of those two companies could be merged and spun off. That is a report according to "Financial Times."

Let's get back to Ford now because it may still face pressure over the tire debacle. But how much long-term impact will there be?

We're joined now by David Bradley, auto analyst at J.P. Morgan, who attended today's Ford meetings.

David, welcome to the program.

DAVID BRADLEY, J.P. MORGAN: Thank you.

VARNEY: Ford has a $5 billion stock buyback program. It's just withdrawn from its association with Daewoo, could save it billions of dollars, the stock's close to a 52-week low. Where's that stock going?

BRADLEY: It'll be at $30 in the next two weeks would be my guess, and it may go higher after that. I think this is a great opportunity. The stock's been knocked down by $5 because of this debacle with the tire recall. It's lost $8 billion of its market cap, $8 billion of its value. The cost of this recall is going to be a small fraction of that, hence there's a big upside. And they're launching a buyback program just at the right moment, when the stock is really very cheap, they can get a lot of stock by it.

VARNEY: Do you think Ford is getting the better of this battle with Firestone in a public relations sense, in a judicial sense, a regulatory sense as well?

BRADLEY: I think they are at the margin, but they're suffering a lot as well. They're not getting a lot of credit in the public arena, and I don't know if it doesn't get worse before it gets better because we got documents submitted today. Those will start leaking out next week of who knew what and when. And there could be all kinds of public relations issues with Ford. But the issue is the consumer who buys a car doesn't care about all that. They want the best-looking car, the best performance at the best price. And that may very well be a Ford Explorer, and that's what they're going to buy. So Ford's earnings aren't going to be materially affected by this.

VARNEY: Absent this problem, absent this dispute, what does Ford look like as a stand alone motor company? Is it in good shape?

BRADLEY: I think Ford is the strongest financial -- financially, the strongest of the Big 3 auto companies, and it's had the best marketshare trends and the best track record, and I think that's the one to own right now.

VARNEY: Do you think Jacques Nasser's job is at stake here?

BRADLEY: I don't think so. Obviously, his style overall has been very aggressive. That ruffles a lot of feathers. His appearances in Congress, in front of the Congress, have created some controversy. But he's -- I didn't think he's in trouble in the short run.

VARNEY: To summarize, you think that Ford stock is at $30 a share in about two weeks?

BRADLEY: That's my opinion.

VARNEY: David Bradley, J.P. Morgan, thanks so much for joining us, sir.

BRADLEY: Thank you.

VARNEY: Willow.

BAY: Stuart, still to come, the debate over the presidential debates continues. We'll bring you the latest in the "MONEYLINE News Digest."

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Turning to news outside the business world, Joie Chen joins us from the CNN Center in Atlanta with the "MONEYLINE News Digest" -- Joie.

JOIE CHEN, CNN ANCHOR: Good evening, Willow, thanks.

The presidential candidates have agreed to debate three times, but their advisers are having trouble working out the details now. Aides to Al Gore and George W. Bush met in Washington today to discuss formats and moderators. At the end of the day, they had no agreement and said they would continue to talk tomorrow. An aide to Gore said the two sides were considering different formats, including making one debate a town-hall meeting, and using a talk show setting for another. Out campaigning today, Bush was in the key state California, where polls show him running behind Democrat Gore now. He talked about education reform at an elementary school in San Diego, and then addressed a rally marking POW/MIA Recognition Day.

Education was also on Mr. Gore's agenda. He visited Howard University in Washington. Gore promised that if elected he would make going to college more affordable.

At the White House today, President Clinton hosted India's Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee. Clinton praised Vajpayee for a moratorium on further nuclear testing and said that he welcomed a warming of relations between the United States and India.

Also today, New York's Mayor Rudy Giuliani says he is feeling fine after a hospital procedure to treat his prostate cancer. Giuliani had radioactive seed implantation, which he said was the best treatment for him at this stage of his disease.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MAYOR RUDY GIULIANI (R), NEW YORK CITY: The process is an excellent one. It's a good one. I went through it with remarkably little pain or discomfort -- no discomfort really. And that's been true throughout.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHEN: Giuliani dropped out of the New York Senate race against Hillary Clinton in April, shortly after he was diagnosed with cancer.

These are some of the top stories of the day. Join us for more news on "THE WORLD TODAY," coming up at 8:00 p.m. Eastern, 5:00 Pacific -- Willow and Stuart.

VARNEY: All right, thank you, Joie.

In tonight's "Tech Watch," another dot.com handing out pink slips. Web portal AltaVista said today it's cutting 225 jobs. That is one-quarter of its workforce. The company also said it's getting out of the media networking business. It's going to focus on its search technology. The moves are part of a major restructuring plan to help it achieve profitability. It postponed its initial public offering back in April. AltaVista is majority-owned by Internet incubator CMGI, and on today's news CMGI lost nearly 2 1/2 points -- Willow.

BAY: Stuart, coming up on MONEYLINE, trouble in the bond pits: why positive signs on inflation couldn't keep Treasury prices out of the doghouse.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Ahead in our next half hour, more details from the "Financial Times" on possible link-ups between units of AT&T and BT.

VARNEY: Plus, tallying the damage: We'll look at which stocks got hit the hardest in today's Wall Street wipeout.

BAY: And we'll assess the impact of resurgent oil prices not just on stocks but on the economy.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's headlines, tech stocks take a drubbing, undercut by concerns over the revenue stream at Oracle.

And oil prices shoot to the highest levels since the Gulf War as the White House warns Iraq about renewed tension in the Mideast.

Plus, the golden arches may be a global icon of American fast food, but sagging sales have made investors sick to their stomachs. The "Bottom Line" at McDonald's.

VARNEY: And we have a major telecom story, courtesy of "The Financial Times." The FT is reporting that AT&T and British Telecom are in advanced talks toward a major restructuring.

The two firms would combine their wireless operations into a separate stand-alone company and would do the same with their business service units. AT&T and BT would each hold on to its domestic consumer operations. All told it would create four distinct companies out of the two current firms. The FT reporting the moves as an effort to boost their sagging share prices: AT&T down about 37 percent this year.

BAY: Our other top story tonight: Just when you thought September couldn't get any worse for your portfolio, guess again. Techs tumble on Wall Street, taking a huge bite out of both the Dow and the Nasdaq. The Dow industrials posting its biggest one-day loss since July. The blue chip average now back below that key 11000 level.

Tech and financial stocks the biggest drag on the Dow today. The industrials down more than 160 points to close at 10,927. The Dow losing more than 2 1/2 percent for the week.

The Nasdaq had an even worse session today, in percentage terms. The tech heavy index sank more than 2 percent, down 78 points, to close at 3,835. For the week, the Nasdaq is down more than 3 1/2 percent.

Today's sell-off spread to the S&P 500 index as well: that down 15 points to 1,464.

Checking some of the day's biggest losers, Dow component Hewlett- Packard lost more than three and is down more than 9 percent this week alone. Fellow Dow component J.P. Morgan lost more than six.

On the Nasdaq, Oracle fell more than 6 1/2 despite yesterday's better-than-expected profit report. Chip stocks also lower: PMC Sierra sank more than eight and Broadcom fell 4 1/2 -- Stuart.

VARNEY: All right, Willow. Today capped off a turbulent week for those chip stocks, turbulent indeed, but semiconductors weren't the only group hurting on the Nasdaq.

Allan Chernoff joins us now with more on what's behind all this tech trouble -- Allan.

ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN CORRESPONDENT: OK, Stuart.

We're still hearing many money managers talking up their favorite tech stocks. And surely there are investors following that advice, buying on the dips. But this week, it seemed every time bidders pushed tech stocks up, a flood of sellers overwhelmed them.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(voice-over): Bad enough that the Nasdaq took a hit this week. Even worse, the pattern of the decline: Monday, a rally that failed; yet another failure on Tuesday; a 44 point gain on Wednesday but Thursday's big rally fell apart; and Friday was a loser from the opening bell.

PHILIP ROTH, MORGAN STANLEY DEAN WITTER: The normal pattern in the market is for the intraday pattern to be in the direction of the trend. So if the trend is up, the daily pattern tends to be up down up. If the trend is weak, the daily pattern will be down up down. So a poor close is a sign of a weak trend.

CHERNOFF: The trend is so weak that Roth believes the Nasdaq could fall another 700 points, back to its lows of May before regrouping late this year.

Earnings anxiety is also weighing on many Nasdaq stocks. Bank of America this week sparked worries that Intel may have slowed production of the Pentium III chip. Intel wouldn't comment, but the stock and the entire sector took a hit.

Then Oracle's battering Friday, down 8 percent even though the software giant delivered better-than-expected profits. The market's response created a sense that leading tech stocks may be overpriced.

Some money managers argue even corporate executives are losing faith.

COURTNEY SMITH, ORBITEX GROUP OF FUNDS: We've also got record- setting insider selling, particularly in the tech sector. And finally, we're seeing also a significant amount of institutional selling in these markets because I think the institutions believe that tech stocks are overvalued.

CHERNOFF: The week's biggest losers among Nasdaq big caps: BMC Software, down 19 percent, fiber optic firm Metromedia Fiber, telecom service provider MCLeodUSA, Intel, and NextLink Communications.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF: So far this month the Nasdaq is down 8.8 percent. That is very close to the unofficial definition of a correction on Wall Street, a 10 percent loss. It also means the bulk of the Nasdaq's 11 1/2 percent gain during August is now gone -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Ouch, that hurts. Allan Chernoff, thanks very much -- Willow.

BAY: Stuart, also under pressure recently: bond prices, the 30- year bond plummeting the past two sessions, down more than two full points, and that has pushed long-term interest rates to their highest levels since July.

The yield on the 30-year Treasury now above that of a 10-year note. The 30-year bond sinking nearly one and a quarter today, pushing the yield up to 5.90 percent. Even the noninflation news couldn't help the long bond today. The Consumer Price Index fell unexpectedly last month, dropping for the first time in more than a decade.

Ceci Rodgers has more from Chicago.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CECI RODGERS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): A sharp drop in energy costs in early August was responsible for the surprise drop in overall consumer prices last month. The Consumer Price Index fell 1/10 of a percent for the first time in 14 years. But core inflation rose 2/10, in-line with expectations.

Rising airfares as well as higher prices for prescription drugs, housing and apparel pushed up the core rate.

ROBERT BRUSCA, ECOBEST CONSULTING: This is a little bit like getting a bigger-than-expected package and a much prettier wrapping and a huge bow, but you open it up and it's exactly what you thought you were going to get.

RODGERS: Economists pointed to a continued acceleration of services costs, which make up about 60 percent of the CPI. Rising medical care costs were the main culprit. Economists said the Federal Reserve will be closely watching that trend.

PAUL KASRIEL, NORTHERN TRUST COMPANY: As we say in Chicago, wait until next year. Well, we don't have to wait until next year. Let's wait until next month, and I think the CPI will be sending a much different message than it did for the August data.

RODGERS: Bond traders looked past the August CPI numbers and focused instead on surging oil prices, sending long-term Treasuries sharply lower for a second day. But the main impetus was a massive shift out of long bonds as investors re-evaluated the chances for a lasting budget surplus.

BILL HORNBARGER, AG EDWARDS: There's talk about tax cuts and more spending, and people are thinking maybe the buyback program is not going to be as aggressive in the years ahead depending on the outcome of the election. I think that's also weighing on the long end of the yield curve.

RODGERS: As a result, the yield curve for 10- and 30-year Treasuries turned positive for the first time since January.

(on camera): With oil prices soaring, there's little relief from inflation worries even as the government's reports on wholesale and consumer prices show little upward pressure in August.

Ceci Rodgers, CNN Financial News, Chicago.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: Coming up, oil prices soar again, shaken by a threat from the past. Could tensions in the Gulf send crude prices into the stratosphere?

We'll be back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Oil prices surged again today, touching fresh 10-year highs as long-simmering tensions in the Mideast boiled over. Iraq accused Kuwait of pumping too much petroleum from fields along their shared border. Kuwait denied the charge, but it was precisely this issue that preceded Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait, and the tensions prompted the U.S. government to warn Baghdad that American forces would defend any threat to Kuwait.

The news, however, sent light sweet crude prices shooting up $1.85 a barrel. A powerful reaction to that from some major oil stocks: ExxonMobil jumped 3 3/4 and hit a new 52-week high, Texaco rose 2 1/2, Chevron gained nearly three, BP Amoco and Royal Dutch also ended higher.

BAY: But the effect of oil prices on the overall market was hardly so positive.

Terry Keenan has been following the fallout -- Terry.

KEENAN: Well, Willow, oil has been going up and the euro has beeng going down since the start of 1999. But this was the week that the markets finally began to stand up and take notice of both those trends. In fact, Wall Street has been pretty blase about oil's relentless run all year, lulled by the perception that $30-dollar-a- barrel oil wasn't here to stay.

Well, that all changed this last week. With crude now hovering around $36 a barrel, up from just $10 in late 1998, there is growing anxiety about the impact on the U.S. economy. Alan Sinai, a global economist at Primark Decision Economics, estimates that the oil-price shock is equivalent to a $100 billion tax increase. And that, combined with the six interest-rate hikes from the Fed over the last year, could mean that the Fed's soft-landing will finish with a thud.

Indeed, that was what the market was saying today, as investors piled out of the technology and cyclical stocks and into the oil issues. The Amex oil index tonight closing at a new high, as investtors are finally embracing the idea that higher oil prices may stick. Now, as for the tech stocks, why was there so much selling there? Well, there was a lot of talk today that while a soft-landing might not be felt much among the new-economy names, a harder landing would truly take the wind out of some of these high-priced stocks.

About the only bright spot investors could point to today on the Nasdaq was a heavy calendar of events next week that could pump some of these names. On the docket, we have an analysts' meeting for Amazon an eBay, Monday and Tuesday, respctively -- then later on in the week, the SG Cowen tech conference, Prudential's Internet and telecom conference, and the Lehman Brothers' wireless conference.

Look for a lot of hype from those events. But whether it can stem the very negative sentiment on the Nasdaq, that's another story -- Willow.

BAY: Terry, we'll wait and see -- Terry Keenan, at the Big Board, thanks.

VARNEY: Now, just ahead: Is Nasdaq 3000 right around the corner? We will talk to one veteran market-watcher who thinks the tech sell-off still has a way to go.

And that's next on MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's "MONEYLINE Focus," we take an in-depth look at today's tech sell-off. The Nasdaq fell into the red again today, topping off a volatile month so far in which the tech-heavy index has plunged more than 8 percent. So, how much worse can it get? Our next guest predicts the Nasdaq will hit 3000 before year's-end, a level we haven't seen since last November. He's Bill Meehan, market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald.

Bill, welcome.

BILL MEEHAN, CANTOR FITZGERALD: Thanks, Willow.

BAY: So I gather you think if we are headed towards 3000, we are going to have more weeks like this one. Why?

MEEHAN: Well, we have great expectations built into most of the tech leadership. Technically, we have seen some major breakdowns. Earlier in the week, we tested the 61.8 percent Fibanochi (ph) retracement of the early-August to early-September move. So we have the Nasdaq breaking down, basically, in most of its leadership.

BAY: So we actually heard Allen report about this -- this pattern, as you alluded to, of sort of these failed rallies. What's that telling you about the sentiment? You're on that trading floor everyday.

MEEHAN: Well, sentiment, you know, is getting a little bit more dreary, but only anecdotally. This current week, we saw Investors Intelligence report 50 percent of newsletter writers are still bullish. And that increased over the last week. And I didn't catch this week's number from the American Association of Independent Investors. But last week, the percentage of bears was only 8 percent. I don't recall single digits before.

BAY: And you think that's way too optimistic?

MEEHAN: Yeah, I think so. More and more people have bought into this notion of a era, or a new economy -- or Internet economy. And I think we have to have prices readjusted downward.

BAY: Because the fact of the matter is -- what you're suggesting -- is that techs are not vulnerable to a slowdown?

MEEHAN: Well, many people thought that was the case. But I think we are in the beginning process of showing that that certainly isn't. Clearly, only new-area economy stocks don't sell among themselves. And if we do have a slowdown in the economy, it will impact these stocks.

BAY: All right, now, I know that you have some advice. When you talk about techs, you say stay out of semiconductors. Why, the easy money has been made there?

MEEHAN: I think the easy money has been made there. By historical measurements, they are trading at very high price-to- earnings multiples, discounting no cyclicality whatsoever. You're going to see a lot of capacity come on board next year. We're already seeing DRAM prices decline.

BAY: And you suggest, though, that investors might want to take a look at some other names. One of them is Qualcomm. Why, because of that good news out of China?

MEEHAN: Well, there was partially that. But really, the reason to own Qualcomm was never just because they had such a dominant position in Korea, which hurt them, and not because they were going to do a deal with China immediately. It's the technology underlying it. And last year, it got ridiculously valued. I think it makes more sense now for long-term investors and technlogy sector, which you don't want to completely abandon.

BAY: OK, Bill Meehan, thanks for joining us tonight on MONEYLINE.

MEEHAN: My pleasure, Willow.

BAY: Stuart.

VARNEY: Thank you, Willow.

Next on MONEYLINE: one of the worst Dow performers this year. We'll have the "Bottom Line" on McDonalds: a fast food landmark faltering. What exactly is troubling the golden arches?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: Now, the "Bottom Line," our regular Friday feature inside one company facing a critical challenge. Tonight, it's McDonald's; The fast food chain is without a doubt one of the world's best-known brands. But that global scope leaves McDonald's prey to currency issues, with the company just this week warning that the weak euro would hurt its profits. But the currency issue is just one threat to McDonald's, a stock hovering near two-year lows.

Peter Viles now has the "Bottom Line."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): It's a scene repeated five times a day, usually outside the United States. McDonald's opens a new restaurant adding to the 28,000 it already has, more than half of them abroad. Expansion is the key to McDonald's growth, the main reason that over the past 15 years it has usually delivered for investors.

Over that time, McDonald's shares gained 647 percent, just slightly trailing the S&P 500.

STACY JAMAR, BANC OF AMERICA SECURITIES: In a lot of ways, I think of McDonald's as a factory that knows how to churn out restaurants.

VILES: But lately McDonald's has stumbled, particularly overseas. Same-stores outside the United States fell 2 percent in August. Domestic sales have been soft as well, and the stock is 42 percent below its peak reached last November.

The question for investors: Has the stock fallen so far it's now a cheap way to invest in the global economy? Analyst Mark Kalinowski.

MARK KALINOWSKI, SALOMONSMITH BARNEY: I do think it's a very attractive valuation at this level, selling at about 16 times next year's earnings estimate of $1.69 a share. We haven't seen McDonald's trade at these level for about two years.

VILES: But with the weak euro cutting into profits in Europe, analyst Stacy Jamar downgraded the stock this week.

JAMAR: The concerns that I am increasingly having is that the same-store sales numbers they're turning in from around the world are mediocre.

VILES (on camera): There's nothing mediocre in the story of how McDonald's was built, and it's a story that should give hope to entrepreneurs of any age, because the man who built this company, Ray Kroc, was 52 years old when he started.

Dick and Mack McDonald opened the first drive-in San Bernardino, California in 1948. Six years later, salesman Ray Kroc of Illinois took note of how many of his milkshake mixers the restaurant was buying. He bought the franchise rights and built McDonald's into a global powerhouse, 5,000 outlets by the late '70s, when some thought McDonald's was as big as it would ever get.

JAMAR: During the '70s, way before I was following this group, people apparently were saying every month that McDonald's is saturated, it can't grow anymore in the U.S., can't do it, can't do it.

Well, in 1970, the average American -- all men, women and children spent just over $3 at McDonald's per year. Last year, it was $69. So the thing that's changed is we eat more fast food than we used to.

VILES: Like Coca-Cola, McDonald's is now a global brand that works hard for every percentage point of growth. Revenue growth, driven by those five new stores a day, has averaged 8 percent over the past four years. Earnings growth has averaged 9 percent. The main problem now in the U.S. has been a lack of hot promotions that draw children to the restaurant.

Internationally, McDonald's faces a host of problems, the weak euro, a new consumption tax in Australia, soft consumer spending in Japan and Brazil, and high gas prices everywhere, which function as a tax on consumers.

But there are positives here as well. CEO Jack Greenberg has improved the relationship between McDonald's and its franchisees. Wall Street considers the company's new made-for-you cooking system a modest hit, and consumers appear to agree. McDonald's has held its lead in the perennial burger wars, with 43 percent of the U.S. Burger market: more than double Burger King's share and more than triple Wendy's share.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: One challenge for McDonald's as the biggest fast-food chain is responding to smaller and more nimble competitors. McDonald's recently hired a consulting firm that uses military planning strategies to help big corporations become faster and more flexible -- Stuart.

VARNEY: With nearly 30,000 restaurants worldwide, surely you could make the case that now in some markets they're saturated.

VILES: Perhaps getting there in North America, but analysts really believe there's a lot of room for this company to grow in Asia, in Latin America and the rest of the globe.

VARNEY: All right, Peter Viles, thanks very much -- Willow.

BAY: Stuart, up next, "Ahead of the Curve": some of what you need to know before those markets open again on Monday. You are watching MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Checking some of what could move the markets next week, look for a new batch of earnings. Starting the week off, retailer Circuit City. The company warned it would miss second-quarter estimates last week. Also reporting, Wall Street heavyweights Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, and tech giant CMGI. On the economic front, look for housing starts for August and international trade for July. Also on Monday, Fed chairman Alan Greenspan speaks before the American Bankers Association on banking supervision.

And to stay a step ahead of the markets, tune into "AHEAD OF THE CURVE" every day at 5:00 a.m. Eastern right here on CNN.

And MONEYLINE wants to hear from you. Send us your comments, questions and feedback by e-mail to moneyline@cnn.com.

VARNEY: And this programming note: some exciting things we'll be bringing you next week and beyond. Monday night, we talk with Mark Moody-Stuart. He is the chairman of the world's second-largest oil and gas company, Royal Dutch Shell: that as oil prices hit 10-year highs.

Also starting Monday and each night for the next two weeks, we'll introduce you to a stock-picking star. In a rough year for the markets, these fund managers have delivered double-digit returns. Who they are and which stocks they're buying now, we're going to tell you.

And next week, a three-part investigative series on "Family Business: The Mob on Wall Street." How well do you know your broker? A disturbing look at crime, corruption and lifesavings lost.

BAY: That is MONEYLINE for this Friday. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney. Good night from New York and enjoy that weekend.

"CROSSFIRE" is next.

DETROIT, MI / ACCESSWIRE / February 9, 2018 / Throughout 2017, banks, financial institutions, and other corporations adopted blockchain technology dramatically faster than initially expected, said . In September, that 15 percent of top global banks rolled out at least one full scale, commercial blockchain product that year, with the figure expected to increase to 65 percent by 2019. Consequently, the adoption rate is expected to rise at an even quicker pace in 2018, as more traditional institution and FinTech giants continue to find ways to implement the innovative technology into their operating procedures. Demand for the blockchain, best known for supporting bitcoin, is growing so much that it will be one of the largest users of capacity in 2018 at more than rented out by IBM to other companies around the globe, said the panel. As one of the first big companies to recognize the technology's promise, IBM has contributed to an open source effort.

IBM has even encouraged startups to try the blockchain on its cloud for free, creating opportunities for both small businesses and large corporations attempting to innovate. As a result, the technology has garnered interest from big tech and financial multinationals alike. In early November, startup company announced that it now has over 60 clients, including Microsoft and Intel, actively using its blockchain platform, also known as a distributed ledger technology, to store vast amounts of data across a network of computers around the world, rather than on one local server. In its announcement, R3 added that more than 100 banks, insurance firms, regulators and trade associations have signed on to collaborate as members, a further sign of growing acceptance. Essentially, the blockchain enables companies and individuals doing business with each other to record transactions securely. Its strength lies in its trustworthiness, explained the panel, as it is impossible to reverse or change what has been recorded. I can also hold infinitely more documents and data than traditional database storage, allowing businesses for more nuances insights and analysis. Almost six in 10 large corporations are considering using blockchain, according to a survey of 400 executives, managers and tech staff. The technology is increasingly being tested or used by companies including Wal Mart and Visa to streamline supply chain, speed up payments and store records. Within five years, digital distributed ledgers will be utilized by 55 percent of companies with more than 1,000 employees. is the world's first socially and environmentally conscious cryptocurrency. urn:contentItem:5RMR-WBP1-JCMN-Y0YV-00000-00Pura Cryptocurrency Examines the Rising Tide of Corporate Blockchain Adoption2018-02-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:25ZLexisNexisPura Cryptocurrency Examines the Rising Tide of Corporate Blockchain AdoptionTanya

Feb 13, 2018( MarketersMedia News Hub: http://marketersmedia.com/news-hub Delivered by Newstex) Demand for the blockchain is growing so much that it will be one of the largest users of capacity in 2018.Detroit, MI - February 12, 2018 /MarketersMedia/ — Throughout 2017, banks, financial institutions and other corporations adopted blockchain technology dramatically faster than initially expected, asserted Pura Cryptocurrency[1]. The International Business Machine Corps. (IBM) reported in September, 2017 that 15 percent of top global banks rolled out at least one full scale, commercial blockchain product that year, with the figure expected to increase to 65 percent by 2019. Consequently, the adoption rate is expected to rise at an even quicker pace in 2018, as more traditional institution and FinTech giants continue to find ways to implement the innovative technology into their operating procedures. Demand for the blockchain, best known for supporting bitcoin, is growing so much that it will be one of the largest users of capacity in 2018 at more than 60 data centers rented out by IBM to other companies around the globe, said the Pura panel.

As one of the first big companies to recognize the technology's promise, IBM has contributed to an open source effort. IBM has even encouraged startups to try the blockchain on its cloud for free, creating opportunities for both small businesses and large corporations attempting to innovate. As a result the technology has garnered interest from big tech and financial multinationals alike. In early November, startup company R3 announced that it now has over 60 clients, including Microsoft and Intel, actively using its blockchain platform, also known as a distributed ledger technology, to store vast amounts of data across a network of computers around the world, rather than on one local server. In its announcement, R3 added that more than 100 banks, insurance firms, regulators and trade associations have signed on to collaborate as members, a further sign of growing acceptance. Essentially, the blockchain enables companies and individuals doing business with each other to record transactions securely. Its strength lies in its trustworthiness, explained the Pura Cryptocurrency[2] panel, as it is impossible to reverse or change what has been recorded. I can also hold infinitely more documents and data than traditional database storage, allowing businesses for more nuances insights and analysis. Almost six in 10 large corporations are considering using blockchain, according to a Juniper Research survey of 400 executives, managers and tech staff. The technology is increasingly being tested or used by companies including Wal Mart and Visa to streamline supply chain, speed up payments and store records. Within five years, digital distributed ledgers will be utilized by 55 percent of companies with more than 1,000 employees. Pura Cryptocurrency[3] is the world's first socially and environmentally conscious cryptocurrency. As an international digital currency, it liberates users to transact with anyone in the world directly, privately and instantly across a peer-to-peer network that is secured by the blockchain. As a conscious cash movement for the common good, ten percent of all PURA created is contributed to PURAPlanet, a treasury trust dedicated to fund and track sustainable, environmental, and social projects around the globe.
